metadata.title: Patients with Pacemakers, and Exercise
anatomical location body part affected: Heart/sinoatrial (SA) node and/or atrioventricular (A V) node; sometimes also the His-Purkinje system of bundle branches
description: An implanted cardiac pacemaker is a pulse generator that contains a battery, electronics, and leads. The leads travel to the myocardium and send depolarizing pulses as well as monitor electrical activity of the heart. The stimulus applied to the heart is measured by amplitude (volts) and duration (milliseconds). Optimization of these measurements is important to prolong battery life and reduce risk of stimulation of nearby tissues, such as the phrenic nerve(1)

The most common indications for placement of a pacemaker are(1,2) –HR that is too slow and associated with symptoms (symptomatic bradycardia) –HR that fails to increase appropriately with exercise or general physical activity (chronotropic incompetence [CI]) –diseases of the A V node, sinus node, or His-Purkinje  system that disrupt cardiac signaling and are due to inflammation, infarction, aging, or fibrosis –sinus node dysfunction –acquired atrioventricular (A V) block –chronic bifascicular block –following acute myocardial infarction –after cardiac transplantation –congenital heart disease –hypertrophic cardiomyopathy –neurocardiogenic syncope and hypersensitive carotid sinus syndrome –tachycardia –cardiac resynchronization therapy for patients with severe systolic heart failure
CI occurs when the heart is unable to achieve 70% of the age-predicted  HR maximum (or 100bpm) during maximum physical exertion;(1) it can contribute to disability and a reduction in ADLs(3)
Pacemaker implantationimprovesCI (i.e., increase in HR and thus cardiac output) during exerciseusing an accelerometer that detects motion of the body(1)

An exercise performance test is important for assessment of pacemaker HR responsiveness and patient signs, symptoms, and physical capacity; all provide a rational basis for the exercise prescription(3,4)

Prescribed exercise training is indicated in patients with pacemakers to counteract the cardiovascular deconditioning and muscle atrophy that may have developed because of disability, as well as to further improve functional capacity, hemodynamic measures, physical activity, and quality of life(3,5)

This review does not discuss special conditions that may also cause symptomatic bradycardia and be indications for a permanent pacemaker, including post-myocardial  infarction, cardiac transplantation, neuromuscular disease (e.g., myotonic dystrophy, Erb dystrophy, Emery-Dreifuss  muscular dystrophy), sleep apnea syndrome, or cardiac sarcoidosis.(4) This review also does not cover patients at increased risk of sudden cardiac death who have a permanent pacemaker with cardioverter defibrillator(4)

ICD-10 codes.Z95.0: presence of cardiac pacemaker (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage; no specific special agencies are applicable for this condition. No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement has been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Bradyarrhythmia, sinus node dysfunction, or A V conduction deficit
Some patients may be asymptomatic Causes, Pathophysiology, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stop the exam and notify physician if patient reports unexpected symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, etc.

CI is common in patients with pacemakers.(3,4,8) Assessment of the patient’s chronotropic reserve (see Special tests , below) should be conducted to determine the peak oxygen consumption using cardiopulmonary exercise testing(8)

Contraindications for exercise testing and training(3) –Up to 2 days after acute coronary syndrome –Severe untreated cardiac arrhythmias –Cardiac thrombus –Acute heart failure with hemodynamic instability –Acute systemic illness –Uncontrolled hypertension –Severe obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy –Advanced A V block  –Aortic stenosis –Acute myocarditis and pericarditis

potential causes of reduced functional c: Prolonged illness with extended physical inactivity leading to:–muscle weakness–cardiovascular deconditioning
Impaired muscle function, as suggested by atrophy, poor strength, and insufficient peripheral O2 utilization duringfatigue-limited exercise(3)
Decreased ability to regulate HR: delayed increase in HR with exercise, submaximal peak HR, HR instability duringexercise, or inadequate recovery of HR(8)

CI: the failure of HR to increase normally during ADLs, or the inability to achieve 85% of age-predicted  maximum HRdespite full effort on incremental exercise test testing.(2) Because maximal-achievable cardiac output is reduced, CI limitsVO2  peak and aerobic exercise performance(8)
Poor chronotropic reserve (i.e., peak achievable exercise HR minus resting HR)
pathophysiology: The major cardiac conduction defects that indicate pacemaker implantation:–Sinus node dysfunction/Sick sinus syndrome: characterized by paroxysmal or chronic sinus arrest(2)–Acquired A V block(2)-Second-degree  A V block type II (Mobitz type II or non-Wenckebach):  sudden interruption of A V conduction withconstant PR interval on ECG-Third-degree  or complete A V block: absence of conduction from atria to ventricles (complete A V dissociation)–Bifascicular block: impaired conduction below the A V node in the right and left bundles of His (2)

SA node disease results in slow and irregular impulse formation,whereas A V node disease slows impulse propagation to thebundle of His. Bifascicular block further slows activation of the ventricles. All three conditions cause:–slow HR associated with cardiac insufficiency (symptomatic bradycardia)–inadequate HR response to physical activity (CI)–irregular slow cardiac rhythm (bradyarrhythmia)

Five-letter  coding identifies the permanent pacemaker type and function; however, it is common to see them referred to byonly the first 3 letters. For example, A VI refers to pacing of the atrium, sensing of the right ventricle, and inhibition of thepacemaker by the patient’s own HR response(7,9)–1st letter: the cardiac chamber(s) containing a pacing lead-A = atrium-V = ventricle-D = dual (both atrium and ventricle)–2nd letter: the cardiac chamber(s) being sensed by the generator-A, V , or D-O = none (sensing function turned off)–3rd letter: adaptive response of pacemaker to sensing patient’s HR-I = inhibited-T = triggered (paces the heart)-D = dual (inhibited or triggered)-O = none (sensing function turned off)–4th letter: ability of pacemaker to vary the HR-O = no rate responsiveness-R = rate modulation according to demand (e.g., exercise)–5th letter: whether the pacemaker has multisite pacing capability (A, V , D, or O), or has an anti-tachycardia function
Rate-adaptive  (I, T, or D) pacemakers affect HR during exercise that can be evaluated for proper response by exercisetesting and, therefore, taken into account when prescribing exercise(8,9)
Numerous studies indicate that rate-modulated  (rate-responsive) pacemakers improve cardiac performance compared tofixed-rate pacemakers(8)
A V sequential biventricular pacing is the best configuration for patients with hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy andimproves quality of life and functional capacity(10)

In heart failure (HF), rate-adaptive  pacing has demonstrated improvements in overall survival and exercise capacity inthose with symptoms of CI(8)–Known as cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT), biventricular pacing is indicated for patients in whom heart failureis diagnosed, who have a wide QRS segment (> 120 ms), or who have a left bundle branch block (LBBB), indicatingcardiomyopathy(3)
Participation in exercise and sport (except collision sports) should be considered for patients with pacemakers who do nothave pathological substrates for fatal arrhythmias(11)
modifiable risk factors that may contrib: Poor adherence to therapeutic regimen, including continued:–smoking–physical inactivity–dietary habits that may promote obesity, diabetes, or hyperlipidemia–abuse of alcohol or drugs

overall contraindications precautions: Restrict patient from raising arms overhead and performing heavy upper extremity activities, such as weight lifting, swimming, golf, or bowling, for 3 to 4 weeks after pacemaker implantation(3)
Any activity that could damage the pacemaker, such as contact sports, should always be avoided(7)
All pacemaker manufacturers offer pacemakers that are safe for MRI; however, older models of pacemakers must be checked for MRI compatibility(7)

Notify physician immediately if patient presents with recent onset of signs and symptoms of acute illness Unusual fatigue Fever Malaise Flulike symptoms (e.g., chills, headache, dizziness, muscle aches) Pulmonary crackles/rales Nausea Diarrhea

Notify physician immediately if patient presents with any complications of pacemaker use. Most complications can be identified in the hospital or within the first 6 months following implantation(2) Bleeding/hematoma or local infection at site of implantation Hiccupping due to stimulation of phrenic nerve (pulse voltage set too high) Angina-like  chest pain (may result from coronary artery disease or venous/cardiac perforation of lead wire) Infections Pericardial effusion or tamponade Pneumothorax Dissection of the coronary sinus Perforation Contraindications to cardiac rehabilitation(12) –Uncontrolled inflammatory or infectious pathology –Symptomatic or severe aortic stenosis –Intracavity thrombus –Complex ventricular arrhythmias –Unstable angina –Severe obstructive cardiomyopathies –Recent thrombophlebitis with or without pulmonary embolism –Acute decompensated congestive heart failure –Severe pulmonary hypertension –Any musculoskeletal condition that disallows exercise participation
There is an increased risk for DVT in the femoral vein when it is used for access; monitor for signs and symptoms (e.g., swelling, redness) and refer to physician immediately should they occur(4)
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

Contraindications for exercise testing and training(3) –Up to 2 days after acute coronary syndrome –Severe untreated cardiac arrhythmias –Cardiac thrombus –Acute heart failure with hemodynamic instability –Acute systemic illness –Uncontrolled hypertension –Severe obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy –Advanced A V block  –Aortic stenosis –Acute myocarditis and pericarditis

course of treatment.medical management: Is the patient being treated for complications of cardiovascular disease (e.g., coronary artery disease, hypertension, HF, chronic renal insufficiency)
course of treatment.medications: Patients with pacemakers often take cardiac medications (e.g., antihypertensives, antiarrhythmic medications, and psychoactive medications(4)), which may affect exercise HR or BP. Document these and confirm that they are being taken
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed: The laboratory workup may include:
treadmill or cycle ergometer exercise test after pacemaker implantation that may be used for exercise prescription(8)
Pharmacologic stress testing (i.e., cardiovascular stress is induced by pharmacologic agents) is indicated when exercise testing is not possible because of physical limitations(4)
Chest X-ray:  identify cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, and pleural effusions(6)
Ambulatory 24-hour  Holter monitoring: assists in monitoring results of antiarrhythmic treatments(4)
CT scan or MRI if structural heart disease is suspected(4)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of herbal, behavioral, or other alternative therapies for health, and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has previously received exercise therapy and what specific program was followed

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before symptoms come on or are eased)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms where applicable
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment. The Borg Rating of Perceived Exertion (RPE) Scale can be used as appropriate (e.g., for patients on betablockers)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: If present, document number of wakings/night; document presence of sleep apnea or other sleep disorder and relevant interventions (e.g., continuous positive airway pressure [CPAP])
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms the patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate inability to exercise and/or symptoms that may indicate referral to physician (e.g., dizziness, chest pain, extreme fatigue) Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document respiratory status and use of any supplemental oxygen, including parameters set by physician. Does the patient have any history of respiratory compromise?Negative emotional states (anxiety, depression, stress, etc.) are closely related to heart disease and may affect outcomes and compliance(13)

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document prior exercise therapy for any other conditions and details regarding history of heart disease
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Is there any history of stroke, kidney disease, diabetes, osteoporosis, or pulmonary or renovascular disease? Also document any history of orthopedic, psychiatric, or neurological disease
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of all prescribed and OTC medications and herbal remedies and use of illegal drugs
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Does the patient want to participate in recreational sports? What does the patient’s occupation involve? Does the patient smoke? To what activities does the patient expect to return? How much daily physical activity does the patient usually get? Does the patient drive? Driving restrictions advise patients with an implanted cardiac device to avoid operating a vehicle for 3 months in Japan and the European Union and for 6 months after last shock in the United States and United Kingdom(14)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: If applicableAsk about family situation, employment status, and working conditions that may increase stress/anxiety

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Is an assistive device being used for ambulation or ADLs?
relevant tests and measures.balance: Confirm that static and dynamic balance reactions are appropriate for use of exercise equipment such as treadmill or elliptical trainer and that the patient is not at risk for falls; use such tests as Berg Balance Scale or Tinetti Balance Assessment Tool
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Confirm that peripheral pulses are present in all limbs
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Confirm normalcy in gross movement during transfers and functional tasks using the upper extremities (e.g., reaching, pulling, pushing, holding) and lower extremities (e.g., steps, squatting, kneeling, kicking)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Prior to prescribing a walking exercise program, confirm that ambulatory function is normal, including synchrony of limb movements and gait speed, as well as posture in walking to allow for most efficient gait –10-meter  walk test for gait speed –Safety with ambulation can be assessed using Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) –Prescribe ambulatory devices as appropriate
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manually scan strength in functional tasks (e.g., handgrip, pushing, pulling, sit-up,  squatting). Assess strength using manual muscle tests (MMT), dynamometry, or weights in muscle groups targeted for exercise training
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess for functional ROM/flexibility in all extremitiesAssess deep tendon reflexesAssess ability to complete self-care  and ADLs; the Barthel Index can be used for objective measure as well as the FIMScan dermatomes for normal sensation
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests –SF-36  Health Survey quality of life assessment –In compliance with medical guidelines, assess HR, BP, and perceived exertion responses, and for adverse signs/symptoms during graded exercise testing on a treadmill or cycle ergometer(3)  –The treadmill test used to evaluate patient performance should allow for gradual progression in exertion as treadmill speed and incline are increased (e.g., in the modified Naughton or Balke protocols)(3) –According to the American Heart Association, exercise testing can also be performed with a cycle ergometer, although oxygen uptake was found to be significantly higher when testing on a treadmill(3) -Pedaling speeds of 50 to 80 rotations per minute resulted in the highest values of HR and VO 2 -Initial power output should be between 10 and 25 watts, with an increase of 25 watts every 2 to 3 minutes until the end of the test is reached –The 6-minute  walk test is often used as an exercise test due to the ease of performing and readministering the test(3)

contraindications precautions: Discussion with the patient’s cardiologist is important regarding medications that the patient is taking and to formulate an appropriate exercise prescription (3)
Exercise testing should be used to evaluate HR and rhythm response prior to beginning an exercise program (3)
When an implantable cardiac defibrillator is present, the peak HR during the exercise test and exercise training program
should be maintained at least 1015  beats per minute below the rate that will trigger shock(3)
After the first 24 hours following device implantation, mild upper extremity ROM activities can be performed and may be useful to prevent subsequent joint complications(7)

To maintain device and incision integrity, for 34 weeks after implant rigorous upper extremity activities such as swimming, bowling, lifting weights, elliptical machines, and golfing should be avoided. However, lower extremity activities are allowed(7)
Systolic BP exceeds 250 mm Hg or diastolic BP exceeds 115 mm Hg(15)
Hypertension is poorly controlled (resting systolic BP > 160 mm Hg)(15)
Systolic BP fails to rise more than 20 mm Hg(11)
Systolic BP progressively drops with exercise(11)
Exertional symptoms such as chest discomfort, dizziness, or dyspnea suggest cardiac insufficiency(15)
Electrotherapeutic modalities are indicated only when prescribed by the referring physician for coexisting conditions

No specific international policies address the use of electrotherapeutic modalities in patients with pacemakers. However, review of the literature and standard practice guidelines based largely on the recommendations from pacemaker manufacturers suggest that TENS and neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES)should be used with much caution. It may be possible to safely administer these modalities for musculoskeletal pain at a safe distance from the pacemaker with close monitoring of the device and patient(16)
Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment regarding the use of modalities
other: Tailor the exercise prescription to fit each patient’s measured functional ability, symptoms, and cardiorespiratory responses to exercise testing(12)
The following considerations should be kept in mind when prescribing exercise for patients with pacemakers:
Monitor BP on a regular basis during exercise. According to standard exercise guidelines, exercise testing or exercise training should be terminated if:
To prevent an exaggerated BP response to exercise, provide the patient with a thorough orientation to using the prescribed exercise equipment with adequate warm-up  time

Research on the safety and appropriateness of resistance exercise (weight lifting) is limited in patients with pacemakers, and thus general guidelines for weight-lifting  exercise are not available specifically for this population
In addition to monitoring HR and BP, use the patient’s perceived exertion and any other symptoms to manage exercise intensity for either aerobic or resistance training

Extend the cooldown period and avoid having the patient stop suddenly after exercise, because this may cause a precipitous fall in systolic BP (orthostatic hypotension and possibly syncope) due to venous pooling
Clinicians should follow the exercise guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician
Patients with osteoporosis should avoid high-intensity  exercise training due to the increased risk of fractures
Contraindications/precautions to use of electrotherapeutic modalities

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Status-post  pacemaker implantation/physical inactivity contributing to reduced functional capacity in ADLs and to increased risk for cardiovascular comorbidities. Cardiac rehabilitation increases quality of life and decreases healthcare costs. It has been shown to increase VO 2 max and improve endothelial function and myocardial reserve flow.(12) In addition, exercise therapy may be indicated for postoperative shoulder pain and reduced function
assessment plan of care.rule out: Angina pectoris, osteoporosis, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral artery disease
prognosis: CI proved to be a prognostic indicator of adverse events in patients with heart failure(4,8)
Authors of a study involving 1118 patients with heart failure found that HR reserve < 60% during exercise was associated with increased all-cause  mortality and all-cause hospitalization(8)
HR recovery after ceasing exercise can be used as a prognostic marker to predict adverse events(8)
In patients with CI, exercise electrocardiographic testing can reasonably provide information on prognosis(4)

Exercise was found to be safe and effective for patients undergoing cardiac resynchronization therapy who had been medically stable for the past month(3) –Aerobic exercise is highly recommended and leads to improvement in functional capacity –Many studies have shown the safety of mild to moderate exercise, but several adverse events have been reported, such as worsening of heart failure and discharge of inappropriate shocks from the pacing device
The impact of stress, depression, and hostile thought patterns on cardiac morbidity and mortality is modest(13)

Mortality after pacemaker implantation varies from 1% to 4% and is affected by the following variables:(6) –Renal failure –High New York Heart Association (NYHA) class –Low ejection fraction –High BMI –Stroke –Low platelet count
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Physician for management of symptoms related to pacemaker syndrome; clinical exercise testing laboratory for direct measurement of VO 2  peak; nutritionist for dietary management and advice on weight control; occupational therapist for limitations in ADLs; psychiatrist/psychologist for stress/anxiety disorder and depression; nurse educator; social worker; smoking cessation program
other considerations: Assessment of VO 2  peak is widely practiced in cardiac rehabilitation programs as a measure of the patient’s cardiorespiratory endurance capacity for physical activities and basis for aerobic exercise prescription, along with activity-related adverse signs and symptoms

VO2  peak can be measured directly in a cardiopulmonary exercise testing laboratory or estimated from standard treadmill or cycle ergometer testing protocols. The 6MWT can be used to predict VO 2  peak(3)
The prescribed exercise training HR should be based on the monitored HR and perceived exertion responses during maximal, symptom-limited treadmill or cycle ergometer testing(3)
Implantation of a permanent pacemaker commonly results in postoperative ipsilateral shoulder pain and disability that indicate the need for physical therapy(19)
treatment summary: Aerobic exercise training  (3) –Patients should exercise 3 to 5 times a week and the duration of each exercise session should be 30 minutes to 1 hour –Intensity of exercise should achieve 80% of the patient’s HR reserve, which could be determined using the 6MWT –The Borg rate of perceived exertion scale could also be used to determine intensity of exercise. Recommended intensity is between 10 and 14 on a 20- point scale to achieve a positive exercise effect –Exercise modalities that could be used include walking aerobic exercises (either using a treadmill or normal walking) or using a stationary bicycle or ergometer –Exercises should be adhered to for at least 8 to 12 weeks –Home exercises can be given to prolong the benefits of exercise

Resistance exercise training –Although exercise therapy should target muscle weakness, the intensity of resistance exercise that is generally safe and effective in patients with pacemakers is unclear –The patient should avoid lifting weights for 3 to 4 weeks after pacemaker implantation(3) –Type of activity: Circuit training.(11) Weight-lifting exercises on machines or using free weights (e.g., leg press, chest press, leg extension, lat pull-down,  leg curls, shoulder press, biceps curl, triceps press)(17,18) –Intensity: Low to moderate intensity.(17) Resistance training at 30–50%  of 1-RM  should be used to build muscular endurance; training at 50–70%  of 1-RM  should be used to increase strength(11) –Duration: 2–3 sets of 10–20  maximal repetitions per exercise, taking about 30 min. to complete the exercise session(18) –Frequency: 2–3 nonconsecutive days per week(11)

Shoulder rehabilitation –Authors of an RCT included 62 pacemaker candidates who were randomly divided into two groups after pacemaker implantation. One group received physical therapy for adhesive capsulitis after device implantation and the other group did not. Authors found that physical therapy and exercise education significantly reduced the incidence of adhesive capsulitis following pacemaker implantation(19) –Specific exercises (3 days per week) involved strengthening and/or stretching shoulder girdle muscles . improved strength: MMT, use of machines or free weights

maintenance or prevention: Continue prescribed exercise training through independent home program
Weight reduction and control, as indicated

Attend regular check-ups  every 3 to 12 months with physician to assess proper functioning of pacemaker(20) Batteries typically last 6 to 10 years; wires may need to be replaced as well Some pacemakers can be checked remotely using a phone or the Internet  –Guidelines updated in 2012 suggest the following minimum frequency of monitoring for pacemakers, implantable cardio-defibrillators,  and CRTs(21) -Within 72 hours of implantation and up to 12 weeks post-implantation,  all monitoring in person -Every 3 to 12 months for pacemaker/CRT-pacemaker,  in person or remote -Every 3 to 6 months for implantable cardio-defibrillators  and CRT defibrillators, in person or remote -Annually until battery depletion, in person -Every 1 to 3 months at signs of battery depletion, in person or remote –Remote monitoring is being researched and has been found to be effective in reducing in-office  visit costs without increasing the risk of major cardiovascular events(22)
